thread.title: More than 330 pilot whales die in New Zealand mass stranding
thread.title_full: More than 330 pilot whales die in New Zealand mass stranding

author: Guardian Staff
title: More than 330 pilot whales die in New Zealand mass stranding
text:
New Zealand More than 330 pilot whales die in New Zealand mass stranding 
On Sunday 220 remain stranded on remote coastline off South Island with 100 returned to sea with the help of volunteers Volunteers look after a pod of stranded pilot whales as they prepare to refloat them after one of the country’s largest recorded mass whale strandings. Photograph: Anthony Phelps/Reuters View more sharing options Close Sunday 12 February 2017 01.48 GMT 
Almost 600 pilot whales have beached themselves off a remote coastline in New Zealand over the past few days in a mass stranding, leaving rescuers struggling to save them. 
By Sunday about 335 of the whales were dead, 220 remain stranded, and 100 were back at sea, the Department of Conservation said. Hundreds of whales die in mass stranding on New Zealand beach Read more 
On Friday morning the department discovered 416 pilot whales had beached themselves at Farewell Spit in Golden Bay at the top of the South Island, with more than 70% dead by dawn. But two additional pods also stranded themselves in the same area over the weekend. 
The department’s Golden Bay operations manager Andrew Lamason told the Associated Press that he was sure rescuers were dealing with a new pod because they had tagged all of the refloated whales from the first group, and none of the new group had tags. 
On Sunday 17 pilot whales that were part of a large pod that stranded on Saturday near Puponga were successfully turned around on the high tide and sent back into deeper water in Golden Bay. 
Two boats were used to guide the whales out to rejoin the original pod, with rescuers hoping that the whales will find a way into deeper, safer waters. Some of the deceased animals have been found with shark bites, and volunteer rescuers have been warned about the possibility of stingrays and sharks. Volunteers try to save whales at New Zealand beach after mass stranding 
Hundreds of volunteers made their way to the beach to help the whales, but on Sunday the department said no more volunteers were required, with parking at capacity and traffic jams in surrounding streets. 
The 240 whales that had stranded between Puponga and Pakawau late on Saturday had mostly refloated themselves on Saturday night’s high tide at 11pm local time and were milling around in shallow water on Sunday. 
It is one of the largest pilot whale strandings in New Zealand, the department said, with rescuers responding to an average of 85 stranding incidents per year, usually of single animals. 
It is unclear while whales strand, though possible theories include navigational error, unusual geographic features, illness and extreme weather events.
